Graham Hovey — Letter from Italy Ho* 15
Recorded In dome, February 5, 1954
Tape runs i 13 *25
(Second In a series of four broadcasts on the Italian parliament In relation
to the January political crisis)
This Is Graham Hoveyf sending from Rome another Letter from Italy, pro*
duced for the Rational Association of Educational Broadcasters with the cooper¬
ation of Radi©television© Italians*
A parliamentary debate In Italy is both similar and strikingly different
from a debate In our own Senate or House of Representatives — and I suppose
there Is nothing very surprising In that.
In Rome, as In Washington, there Is the same bustle as & session gets
underway* fages dart up the aisles with messages for the legislators! a clerk
at a microphone drones on with the reading of the minutes or some other docu¬
ment and no one in the house seems to be paying the slightest attention; mem¬
bers climb the rostrum to confer with the presiding officer, Just as congress¬
men go up to confer with Speaker Joe Martin*
A member of the Chamber of Deputies invariably refers to another member
as "the honorable" so-and-so, whether he really feels that way about him or not*
Thus, Communist leader Ralmlro Togliattl calls former Premier Alcide de Gasperl
"I'onorevol© De Gasperl." It reminds an American of the way two bitter enemies
such as Congressman Emanuel Cellar and ex-Congressman John Rankin would refer
to each other as "the gentleman from Hew fork," and "the gentleman from
Mississippi," respectively*
These are some of the similarities* Then there are the differences —
and some of these strike an American visitor immediately.
One of these differences is obvious, but I think you must visit the
Italian Senate or Chamber to get its full impact* In Washington senators and
congressmen debate the Communist menace. Here in Rome that meance is always
present in strength, ready to take part in the debate* The Communists and their
fellow travelers occupy more than a third of the seats in both houses*
There they are, duly elected by qualified voters, holding a great bloc of
seats on the left side of each chamber, if you are looking down from the ros¬
trum.
There, two thirds of the way up the bank of seats in the Chamber of
Deputies, on the inside of the first section, sits Palmiro Togliattl, number
one man In Italy's Communist hierarchy.
Togliattl is a short man with broad shoulders, but he is slight¬
ly, as though he had suffered from arthritis* His black hair,_Still thick in
most places, is now thinning Just a bit on top, but he hardly looks 61, which
he will be on March 26* He dresses conservatively in dark blue suits and wears
rimless glasses*
He hardly look® like the stereotype of the Communist revolutionary and
many observers believe Togliattl Is quite content for the present to play his
role as parliamentary leader of a powerful minority party, scoring debating
points against the government.
